editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.head: To the READER.
div.p:
THE holy Scriptures that had Å¿o many praiÅ¿es given unto them by the Antients, were by them much read and Å¿tudied; who uÅ¿ed alÅ¿o many waies of interpreting them: wee finde their Commentaries, that is,

ChryÅ¿oÅ¿t. Aug. and others. After his
time Å¿ome wrote Commentaries, but rarely, as Aponius on the Canticles, Claudius SeÅ¿ellius on St. Luke, Angelomus the Monk on the Kings and Canticles, VValafridus Strabus Collector of the Ordinary gloÅ¿Å¿e, and Haimo on S. Pauls EpiÅ¿tles, all of them much about Paul's time. But afterwards much more rarely, PaÅ¿chaÅ¿ius Rabertus Abbot of Corbey wrote upon the Lamentations, and Remigius Monke, and afterwards BiÅ¿hop of Auxerre on the PÅ¿almes, Canticles and Mathew, about An. 880. AmbroÅ¿. Ansbertus, a French Monke, on the Canticles, anno 890. Bruno ArchbiÅ¿hop of Colein on the Pentateuch, an. 937. After him we finde none till Paul of Jenoa wrote on the PÅ¿almes and Jeremy, which was, anno 1054. onely Bale mentions one Serlo a Monk of Dover a Commentator, about anno. 956. And till 1100. or thereabouts, wee finde Å¿ome, as Oecumenius, and the two AnÅ¿elms of Luca and Canterbury, and Stephanus Anglicus, Rupert, Bernard, and Philip, an Abbot in Heinalt, a familiar friend of S. Bernards. But when once Schoole Divinity got the Kingdome, all Å¿tudied that, and laid the Scripture by. Peter ComeÅ¿tor indeed had the Scripture by heart; but his brother Lombard brought AriÅ¿totle into more requeÅ¿t then St. Paul, as the Sorbonne at Paris complained. Then it was that preaching on the Scripture had gone altogether out of uÅ¿e, had not Dominicke a Spaniard, the founder of the Order of Preaching Friars, about an. 1200. commanded his diÅ¿ciples to reade the Scripture, and carry nothing but the Bible with them when they went to Preach. And yet by theÅ¿e pretended friends of the Scripture, was the Scripture likewiÅ¿e trampled upon, who preferred Dominick before St. Paul, according to that Picture of them both in one table,John Wolf. lect. memor. Tom. 1. Cent. 13. ad an. 1205. which John Wolfius tels us, was not much after that time to be Å¿een in Venice; under St. Pauls was writ, By him you may goe to ChriÅ¿t, and under Dominicks Picture; By him you may goe to ChriÅ¿t
more eaÅ¿ily. But that which I Å¿hall content my Å¿elfe with as an inÅ¿tance for all, is that which is reported of Albert ArchbiÅ¿hop of Ments; who being at the Dyet at AuÅ¿bourg, an. 1530. and finding a Bible on the table, and reading Å¿ome leaves where by chance hee opened it, Å¿aid, Truly I know not what booke this is, but this I Å¿ee, that it makes all againÅ¿t us. But when the knowledge of the tongues began to flouriÅ¿h, then the Å¿tudy of Scripture revived: for till a little before the Reformation, there were few or none that cared for, or indevoured any skill in the Greek, much leÅ¿Å¿e in the Hebrew: yea moÅ¿t were then of John Dullards minde, who was Schoole-maÅ¿ter to Ludovicus Vives, and was wont to Å¿ay unto him; The better Grammarian thou proveÅ¿t, Ludov. div.head: The Summe or Argument of the whole PropheÅ¿ie.
div.p:

But they forgetfull of former things, both beatings & benefits, as children are, returned to their Å¿innes, polluted the Divine worÅ¿hip, gave themÅ¿elves to divers vices, began to make marriages with Infidels, againe embraced Polygamy, took up the cuÅ¿tome of giving bills of divorce, committed Å¿acriledges, caÅ¿t out Å¿trange contempts againÅ¿t God, and blaÅ¿phemies: By all which the Lord being againe provoked,

Now it is no hard thing to make the CompariÅ¿on, and apply theÅ¿e things to our times, that it may appeare, the handling of this is no unfit thing, but apt to the time.

For the Å¿innes of the Land God was diÅ¿pleaÅ¿ed, and gave over the people to captivity (though in their owne Land Å¿omewhat leÅ¿Å¿e than this, yet it was) both of body and Å¿oule to a new Nebuchadnezar, which makes it the greater, the Church and Å¿pirituall JeruÅ¿alem much defaced, the Reliques of it partly put to flight, partly to the fire. But Å¿ee how good God was, after a time he brought againe our Captivity. After which he looked for better things from us, and haply had them while the benefit was freÅ¿h, and the bondage yet felt. But Å¿ee, theÅ¿e are worne out of minde, and we againe have committed great Å¿ins againÅ¿t God, by which we juÅ¿tly have provoked Gods indignation againÅ¿t us, yea and alas, we ceaÅ¿e not to provoke it; for how great contempt of the Å¿ervice of God is there in every place? what prophaneneÅ¿Å¿e? what corruption of manners? what unfaithfulneÅ¿Å¿e in covenant breaking? what uncleaneneÅ¿Å¿e in marriage? what
horrible oaths? what fearefull perjuries? what execrable blaÅ¿phemies againÅ¿t the HigheÅ¿t? not in meane perÅ¿ons, but of the higheÅ¿t rankes; not in Countries only, but in famous Cities; not in meane mens Cottages onely, but in noble mens places and Palaces, in Church and Common-wealth: Å¿o that the Lord may Å¿ay to us, as he Å¿aid to IÅ¿rael by Malachy, Chap. 16. becauÅ¿e neither honour nor feare be performed to him. So that not onely juÅ¿t are thoÅ¿e plagues that are come upon us, peÅ¿tilence to the body now almoÅ¿t three yeares, and famine to the Å¿oule begun, and threatned more, but alÅ¿o particular & generall judgments. WhatÅ¿oever is in this PropheÅ¿ie, may juÅ¿tly both be threatned and executed upon us; when it is juÅ¿t with God, where like Å¿ins are, to bring upon them like puniÅ¿hments.
This is the reaÅ¿on of my choyÅ¿e, as alÅ¿o the Å¿umme and argument of this PropheÅ¿ie.

The parts of it are divers. After the InÅ¿cription, or Preface, we have,

All which are to be found promiÅ¿cuouÅ¿ly, and intermixed one with another; the particular reÅ¿olution of which is better in their place, and more
profitable, than now to Å¿pend time in pointing out every particular where it is to be found.

The time when this PropheÅ¿ie was written, is, in generall, after they were returned from their captivity; more Å¿peciall, after Hagge and Zachary, the two Prophets of the Church, and yet more, after the building and finiÅ¿hing the Temple about Å¿ome 24. After whoÅ¿e dayes, in the time of Artaxerxes, Darius his Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿our, our Prophet began to propheÅ¿ie, being the laÅ¿t of all Å¿uch as did propheÅ¿ie till the fore-runner of ChriÅ¿t John the BaptiÅ¿t.

div.p:

BecauÅ¿e it is a juÅ¿t rule of equall recompence, ReaÅ¿on 1 to doe to men as they do to others, much more as they do to him, that when they make him deÅ¿piÅ¿ed and diÅ¿honoured, he Å¿hould make them according to that, 1 Sam. 2.30. To teach the MiniÅ¿ters, if they be in contempt, Æ²Å¿e 3 as who is out of it, to conÅ¿ider the cauÅ¿e of it: for as they Å¿ay, it is the cauÅ¿e that makes the Martyr, not the Å¿uffering; Å¿o in this, the cauÅ¿e affoords comfort or woe. Have I alÅ¿o] You begun and broke covenant with me, and now I have broken with you; not I, but you began firÅ¿t, I onely followed.

He went out to meet AÅ¿a, and Å¿aid unto him, O AÅ¿a, and all Iudea and Benjamin, heare yee me: The Lord is with you while yee be with him; and if yee Å¿eeke him, he will be found of you: but if yee forÅ¿ake him, he will forÅ¿ak you, Jer. 22.13.16.17. &c.

BecauÅ¿e he is immutable, ReaÅ¿on 1 and without change: all the while then they are the Å¿ame, and do performe duties to him, he will not be otherwiÅ¿e; becauÅ¿e then Å¿hould he change, which is not poÅ¿Å¿ible. BecauÅ¿e he is moÅ¿t juÅ¿t, ReaÅ¿on 2 yea JuÅ¿tice it Å¿elfe, one that gives Suum cuique. Now while a man performes his promiÅ¿e, and cleaves to God, he will not with-hold, or forÅ¿ake any thing: for promiÅ¿e is debt.

To teach what is the cauÅ¿e why man often enjoyeth not many of the bleÅ¿Å¿ings which are promiÅ¿ed. VÅ¿e 1 The cauÅ¿e is not in God, not that he hath promiÅ¿ed more then he can performe, for he is allÅ¿ufficient; nor more then he thought fit, for he is moÅ¿t wiÅ¿e in promiÅ¿ing as well as performing. VÅ¿e 2

To inÅ¿truct a man how he may enjoy the bleÅ¿Å¿ings and promiÅ¿es of God, whether one or other: he muÅ¿t keep promiÅ¿e with him, and performe all the conditions on his part. Not his faithfulneÅ¿Å¿e, but his performance: AnÅ¿w. for he may be faithfull, and is undoubtedly Å¿till, without the performance, as he is a faithfull man who never performeth condition with another, when they had broken their conditions of his performing of covenant as before.
I made you to be deÅ¿piÅ¿ed.] It was others malice and corruption, but Gods judgement. Doctrine.

Now he doth order and diÅ¿poÅ¿e of this at his good pleaÅ¿ure, and makes it fall where he thinkes beÅ¿t, where he would puniÅ¿h, and for what end he purpoÅ¿eth, not for what they intended: As Salomon, Prov. 16.1. This may Å¿hew the folly of thoÅ¿e who deÅ¿piÅ¿e and Å¿et naught by the deÅ¿piÅ¿ing and reproaches, VÅ¿e 1 becauÅ¿e they come from inferiours, from baÅ¿e, and meane, and weake men. But theÅ¿e Å¿hould conÅ¿ider that it is not from them, but God, and by them, and are the Å¿igne of his diÅ¿pleaÅ¿ure. It is not to be braved or bragged out: Men may not think to acquit themÅ¿elves by anÅ¿wering one reproach with another, one contempt with another; for this is but to fight againÅ¿t God, who hath made them to deÅ¿piÅ¿e them, who if he can not make to returne with Å¿uch blaÅ¿ts, and Å¿mall windes, hath verily Å¿harpe Arrowes and keene Swords, hath mighty armies, and great Å¿tore of men of armes to Å¿ubdue them.

To teach men when they are in Å¿uch judgements, Æ²Å¿e 2 the way how to have them removed: firÅ¿t to have Davids thoughts; they curÅ¿ed, becauÅ¿e God bids them curÅ¿e, they reproach and contemne them, becauÅ¿e he hath Å¿o made them, and then to imagine and conÅ¿ider that he who Å¿et them on muÅ¿t Å¿nap them & check them. He muÅ¿t onely charme theÅ¿e Adders that they Å¿ting not, or he onely muÅ¿t cure their biting; therefore muÅ¿t they by prayer Å¿eeke unto him for the removing of them who muÅ¿t take theÅ¿e from them, Å¿o David prayed, PÅ¿al. 119.39. Take away my rebuke that I feare: for thy judgements are good. And if he a King of that magnificence and greatneÅ¿Å¿e, of that power and authority could not have them removed but by Å¿eeking to God; if he could not cure the biting of a dead dogge, as AbiÅ¿hai calleth Shimei, but God muÅ¿t doe it; how then Å¿hall any other inferiour man be able to helpe himÅ¿elf and remove it without him? Thirdly, he muÅ¿t humble himÅ¿elfe and remove his Å¿inne which is the cauÅ¿e of fit; for if he remove no judgement unleÅ¿Å¿e man remove the cauÅ¿e; if he give not favour in the eyes of men, unleÅ¿Å¿e they have favour in his owne eyes firÅ¿t, If Prov. 16.7. When the waies of a man pleaÅ¿e the Lord he will make alÅ¿o his enemies at peace with him, Then muÅ¿t they turne unto him, and forÅ¿ake that which is diÅ¿pleaÅ¿ing, and doe that which is acceptable. And if a reproach be, as they Å¿ay of words irrevocable; yet will God doe him good for the others evill, 2 Sam. 16.12.
But yee have beene partiall in the law.] Their particular Å¿inne, why he would lay this judgement upon them; their accepting of perÅ¿ons in the worke of their MiniÅ¿tery.

As it is in a MagiÅ¿trate, Doctrine. and in him that executes judgement, a great corruption to accept perÅ¿ons; Å¿o is it in a MiniÅ¿ter and him that muÅ¿t diÅ¿poÅ¿e of Gods myÅ¿teries. As the MagiÅ¿trate in diÅ¿tributing of juÅ¿tice may not reÅ¿pect poore or rich, friend or foe, high or low, or any thing beÅ¿ides juÅ¿tice and equity; Å¿o muÅ¿t not the MiniÅ¿ter in dividing the word. Therefore are they here reproved
as offendors for doing Å¿o. It is proved by the command to Ieremy, Chap. 1.17.18. Hence is the commandement indefinite and generall to preach to all, and to reprove all. Ezek. 3.18. BecauÅ¿e as IehoÅ¿aphat Å¿ayd of judgement, ReaÅ¿on 1 that it was the Lords and not mans, and therefore perÅ¿waded the Judges to doe it without reÅ¿pect; Å¿eeing God himÅ¿elfe would doe Å¿o, therefore ought they, 2 Chron 19.6, 7. Å¿o of this, the word is the Lords, therefore muÅ¿t they Å¿peake it as he would have them.
BecauÅ¿e they ought to be faithfull diÅ¿poÅ¿ers of Gods myÅ¿teries, ReaÅ¿on 2 fidelity conÅ¿iÅ¿teth in delivering the whole, and in delivering the parts to them for whom God hath appointed them.

To reprove all MiniÅ¿ters who are partiall in the law and dividing of Gods word and myÅ¿teries, Æ²Å¿e 1 reÅ¿pecting perÅ¿ons and accepting faces, they are all guilty of very grievous Å¿in before God; AmongÅ¿t others the whole Cleargy of Rome are guilty of this Å¿inne, having fitted the word and diÅ¿poÅ¿ition of thoÅ¿e myÅ¿teries to every mans humour, as not long Å¿ince was Å¿hewed, when as the word is contrary to every mans humour, as contrary as light is to darkeneÅ¿Å¿e; yet with them they have fitted it, making it as they Å¿peake of it, a Å¿hipmans hoÅ¿e, a noÅ¿e of waxe, a leaden rule. So Pighius and Nicolas CuÅ¿anus a Cardinall of Rome; writeth to the Bohemians, EpiÅ¿t. 2. EpiÅ¿t. 7. This underÅ¿tand that the Scriptures are fitted to the time, and diverÅ¿ly to be underÅ¿tood, Å¿o that at one time they may be expounded according to the coÌmon and cuÅ¿tomable courÅ¿e, but change that and the Å¿enÅ¿e is changed. So that it is no marvaile if the cuÅ¿tome of the Church at one time interpret the Scriptures after this manner, and another time after that; and according to this they Å¿o deale, for time and perÅ¿ons, and Å¿o prove partiall in the the whole. One thing amongÅ¿t other argues the partiallity of the high PrieÅ¿t of Rome, which they wuold perÅ¿wade us is part of the Law and Word of God; that is Purgatory: which they diÅ¿poÅ¿e in reÅ¿pect of perÅ¿ons, the rich and great ones able to give much, Å¿hall not long be in it; they who can give leÅ¿Å¿e, the longer, they who are able to give nothing, perpetually. If he had any charity in him of which they bragge much, he would free all, and freely, Å¿eeing they teach it is the Popes peculium; but if he had but equity and juÅ¿tice in him, he would free one as well as another, and not accept perÅ¿ons, and be thus partiall. But not to trifle with them. The partiallity is oftentimes too papable in the reformed Churches and the MiniÅ¿ters of them, when in dividing the word they looke not as the Cherubimes to the Arke, they to the word to Å¿peake as it would teach them, which is not partiall, but to thoÅ¿e who Å¿it before them
and apply it Å¿o, making it as Å¿ome write of Manna, that it taÅ¿ted after every mans pallat and Å¿tomacke, Å¿o this: But they are guilty of this Å¿inne, and though as fooles and wicked perÅ¿ons, they enjoy honour for a time, yet they Å¿hall have diÅ¿honour, Prov. 3.35. It is Å¿aid of the Panther that he is Å¿o greedy after the excrements of a man that if they be out of his reach and naturall power, he Å¿tretcheth himÅ¿elfe Å¿o much that he kills himÅ¿elfe in the end: Å¿o may I apply it to theÅ¿e.

To perÅ¿wade the MiniÅ¿ters of God not to be partiall, Æ²Å¿e 2 but upright in the law. To reÅ¿pect, as juÅ¿t Judges will doe, the cauÅ¿e, equity, and juÅ¿tice, and not the perÅ¿ons, the honour, or commodity that is to be had by them, not to deale for that partially with the law or in it, but Å¿trive to divide the word of truth aright, and to goe with a right foote unto the GoÅ¿pell, even as God himÅ¿elfe will do, for they are Gods judgements. A MiniÅ¿ters reÅ¿olution Å¿hould be that of Elihu Job 32.21, 22. Remembring that as Saul was put out of the Kalender of Gods Kings, for his partiallity, and is accounted to have reigned but two years, when he did many more: Å¿o Å¿hall they be out of the number of Gods worthies if they be partiall, whereas their uprightneÅ¿Å¿e and faithfulneÅ¿Å¿e will with the good Steward bring them into the joyes of their MaÅ¿ter.

To perÅ¿wade our hearers to give us leave to divide the word without partiallity, VÅ¿e 3 and not to be Å¿wayed with their greatneÅ¿Å¿e and riches, and frowns, and Å¿uch like; but as occaÅ¿ion may be to deale with their Å¿innes, as others, and to give them their portion of judgement as well as mercy, without the knitting of their browes, the Å¿trangeneÅ¿Å¿e of their looke, the cenÅ¿ure at their tables and tavernes, among Å¿uch as are companions with them in the like iniquity; but if they will not, we muÅ¿t take leave, we had rather fall into the hands of men then God, wee know that is a fearefull thing. It is neither your wealth, nor your favour, nor honour, and credit, that either can keepe us from being vile and diÅ¿piÅ¿ed; If God Å¿ay to men, deÅ¿piÅ¿e them; nor will anÅ¿wer for us when we muÅ¿t give an account of our StewardÅ¿hip.

div.head: VERS. X.

argument.p: Have we not all one father? hath not one God made us? Why doe we tranÅ¿greÅ¿Å¿e every one againÅ¿t his brother, and breake the covenant of our fathers?

div.p:
HAve we not all one father?] The Å¿econd part of the Chapter beginneth here and continueth to the end, containing the
reproofe of divers particular vices in the people of IÅ¿rael in generall, both PrieÅ¿t and people, in this tenth verÅ¿e he reproveth their injurious and unequall dealing in the generall.

Have we not all one father?] Some underÅ¿tand theÅ¿e words with the next verÅ¿e, as if it were a reaÅ¿on Å¿poken in the defence of their taking of Idolatrous wives, by them who had done it; their reaÅ¿on is thus: That Å¿eeing that they had all one father, which was Adam, and all one Creator, which was God: there was no reaÅ¿on why they Å¿hould not marry with them. But others doe underÅ¿tand them as two main reaÅ¿ons againÅ¿t their marrying them, urged by the Prophet from God himÅ¿elfe: and Å¿o the expounding of the words will rather confirme, and the greater conÅ¿ent of the learned old and new, goe that way. Hierom Å¿aith that the people being returned out of captivity, the Princes and PrieÅ¿ts, and people put away their wives of the IÅ¿raelites kindred, which by reaÅ¿on of their poverty, and injury of the long way, and weakeneÅ¿Å¿e of their Å¿exe, impatiently bearing the labour, were waÅ¿ted, and became both infirme and deformed in body; whereupon they matched with Å¿trangers, who were freÅ¿h in yeares, beautifull and comely, the daughters of rich and mighty men; as we may Å¿ee in the ninth of Ezra, that is with the Canaanites, Hethites, PhereÅ¿ites, JebuÅ¿ites, Ammonites, &c. Therefore they thinke the Prophet here reproves them; firÅ¿t for their marriages, and after for their divorces, VerÅ¿e 16.

There are two Å¿peciall and chiefe cauÅ¿es of love and good will amongÅ¿t men; the one is kindred, affinity, or conÅ¿anguinity; the other is one and the Å¿ame Å¿ociety of religion. FirÅ¿t, nature compells men to affect and love earneÅ¿tly thoÅ¿e who are borne in the Å¿ame family, deÅ¿cended from the Å¿ame parents and Å¿tocke; which bond cannot be violated or broken off without great wickedneÅ¿Å¿e. Secondly, men reaÅ¿onable and wiÅ¿e, do thinke thoÅ¿e Å¿pecially to be affected by them, who are companions with them in the Å¿ame religion and worÅ¿hip. And though this is the moÅ¿t worthy and Å¿ure, yet the other goes before, and firÅ¿t carries Å¿way with men becauÅ¿e it is by nature bred with them, and continued from their infancie. And theÅ¿e two they are here preÅ¿Å¿ed withall, as thoÅ¿e which condemnes their fact, dealing thus to put away the daughters of IÅ¿rael, the worÅ¿hippers of the true God, and to take unto them the daughters of the heathen, worÅ¿hippers of the falÅ¿e Gods. For the firÅ¿t of theÅ¿e reaÅ¿ons, it is here Å¿aid, Have we not all one Father? That is, are we not all men and women deÅ¿cended from Abraham by one IÅ¿aac, from IÅ¿aac by one Iacob? Why then Å¿hould we thus doe? diÅ¿miÅ¿Å¿e thoÅ¿e, or paÅ¿Å¿e them over, and joyne our Å¿elves to the kindred of the heathen and Å¿trangers? And for the Å¿econd he Å¿aith, Hath not one God made us? Do we not all acknowledge one God the Creator, and worÅ¿hip and Å¿erve him
with dutie? Do you diÅ¿miÅ¿Å¿e thoÅ¿e wives, who acknowledge the Å¿ame Creator with you, and worÅ¿hip him, and take unto you thoÅ¿e who worÅ¿hip Idols for him, and put their truÅ¿t in them? To create, or the Creator, is not here taken in that common Å¿enÅ¿e, as when we Å¿peake of Gods creation of the world: for then could this be no reaÅ¿on againÅ¿t, but rather for them, as Å¿ome would make it a reaÅ¿on in that Å¿ort which the Prophet laboureth to confute. But this being againÅ¿t them, muÅ¿t not be taken in that Å¿enÅ¿e, but in another Å¿enÅ¿e, as there is a Å¿peciall uÅ¿e of it in the Scripture, when it Å¿peaketh and dealeth of Å¿ome new & Å¿ecret diÅ¿poÅ¿ition of things, as Jer. 31.22. And Å¿o it is uÅ¿ed, IÅ¿aiah 65.18. of Å¿uch a Å¿peciall creation is it here meant, where love and dutie is Å¿pecially due unto thoÅ¿e, who are of the Å¿ame religion with us, who follow the lawes and Å¿tatutes of the Å¿ame Creator and Author.

Why do we tranÅ¿greÅ¿Å¿e every one againÅ¿t his brother?] It is taken by Å¿ome to be the reproofe of their vice, though cloÅ¿ely, or not Å¿o openly, as verÅ¿. 11. it is Å¿et downe: i. Å¿eeing we are of one kindred, deÅ¿cended from one father, why do we thus tranÅ¿greÅ¿Å¿e one againÅ¿t another, either putting away, or refuÅ¿ing our owne kindred in reÅ¿pect of Å¿trangers and aliens? Brother, here Å¿ome interpret either the Å¿iÅ¿ter or daughter of our brother; or rather according to the uÅ¿e of the Scripture and Hebrew, which by brother underÅ¿tand the female as well as the Male. And the application according to the occaÅ¿ion either both, or but the one: Both, as Jam. 1.2. and the one, as here upon this occaÅ¿ion, muÅ¿t needs be the female.

And breake the covenant of our Fathers.] Some thinks that this is applied unto the Å¿econd reaÅ¿on; becauÅ¿e the covenant of the Fathers was, That they all, and their whole poÅ¿terity, Å¿hould acknowledge and worÅ¿hip one God onely: and one people Å¿hould be conÅ¿ecrated to one and the Å¿ame God. div.head: To the Reader.
div.p:
IT was not choyce, but occaÅ¿ion that caÅ¿t me upon this Subject. Having the originall notes of the Sermons of that reverend, learned and godly Divine, M. Richard Stock upon this prophet Malachy, entruÅ¿ted into my hands, and upon peruÅ¿all of them finding many neceÅ¿Å¿ary points moÅ¿t wholeÅ¿omely treated of; I thought it too great an injury both to his Name, and to the publicque, to make them onely mine, and to keepe them to mine owne uÅ¿e; and therefore I reÅ¿olved, (not without the judgement and approbation of other men) to communicate them unto the uÅ¿e of others. But withall obÅ¿erving, that his aime being only the edification of a popular audience, he had onely indeavored to apply the Text to the condition of his preÅ¿ent hearers; and had left Å¿omewhat to be done to make it a Compleat Commentary; I Å¿et my Å¿elfe to examine the original, to conferre tranÅ¿lations,
to inquire into the Å¿everall gloÅ¿Å¿es and expoÅ¿itions of the Antients and Modern's; and have thereupon made up what you Å¿ee, by way of Exercitation. Not out of any opinion of mine owne ability, or an ambition to be upon the Å¿tall, or out of any more peculiar delight that I take in this kind of study, which yet is a study moÅ¿t worthy of a Divine, and which may exerciÅ¿e the moÅ¿t able; eÅ¿pecially theÅ¿e more difficile pieces, I meane, the prophecies, which according to the Hieroglyphique of prophecy wch (they Å¿ay) doth hang among other pictures in the VaticaÌ library at Rome, are like Matrones with their eyes covered. Hier; and one that had not any reÅ¿olution againÅ¿t writing, for he wrote other tractes, as VerÅ¿es and EpiÅ¿tles,) would not bee drawne to write commentaries, though he were intreated by many of his friends, as deeming himÅ¿elfe unworthy, though hee were indeed very able. I commend his Å¿pirit, though I follow not his example, and I have given you the excuÅ¿e above.

I have every where followed the Grammaticall, which is the lawfull and
geunine Å¿enÅ¿eIac. Armin DiÅ¿p. priv. TheÅ¿. 9 of Scripture. Men have been too wanton with Allegories Origen, S. AmbroÅ¿e, S. I have alÅ¿o Å¿ought the moÅ¿t proper graÌmaticall Å¿enÅ¿e, not alwayes the firÅ¿t but the moÅ¿t agreeable to the nature of the context; which while it hath not beene obÅ¿erved, many abÅ¿urd interpretations have been made. Not obÅ¿erving the uÅ¿e of that phraÅ¿e among the Hebrewes, which alÅ¿o the Septuagint, the Chalde, the Vulgar Latin, our EngliÅ¿h, and (for ought I know) all interpreters doe expreÅ¿Å¿e, He dyed according to the word of the Lord. But I will not enlarge my Å¿elfe here, becauÅ¿e I Å¿peake unto the Å¿ame point in the EpiÅ¿tle before M. Stocks commentary. I wil only requeÅ¿t this of the learned reader, (if any Å¿uch Å¿hall vouchÅ¿afe to beÅ¿tow his eye Å¿o meanly,) that hee make a favourable judgement of what defect or other blemiÅ¿h hee may diÅ¿cerne in a worke of this nature, wch could not bee Å¿moothly wrought,
nor wrought in all things to mine own Å¿atisfaction, having the uÅ¿e of no books but mine owne, and living almoÅ¿t an 100 mile from any publicque library. Yet Å¿uch as I have, J have not neglected to conÅ¿ult: willing to caÅ¿t off that untrue and Å¿landerous aÅ¿perÅ¿ion which Francis Ribera Riber. Com. in HoÅ¿. 13. Num. 12. hath throwne upon Protestant Jnterpreters; that they reade not the Commentaries of the holy fathers, but being furniÅ¿hed with Å¿ome poore meaÅ¿ure of knowledge in the tongues,Sed vide Guil.
